1: <sup>1</sup> A good name is better than precious ointment; and the day of death than the day of one’s birth.
2: <sup>2</sup> It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting: for that is the end of all men; and the living will lay it to his heart.
3: <sup>3</sup> Sorrow is better than laughter: for by the sadness of the countenance the heart is made better.
4: <sup>4</sup> The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
5: <sup>5</sup> It is better to hear the rebuke of the wise, than for a man to hear the song of fools.
6: <sup>6</sup> For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fool: this also is vanity.
7: <sup>7</sup> Surely oppression maketh a wise man mad; and a gift destroyeth the heart.
8: <sup>8</sup> Better is the end of a thing than the beginning thereof: and the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.
9: <sup>9</sup> Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry: for anger resteth in the bosom of fools.
10: <sup>10</sup> Say not thou, What is the cause that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not enquire wisely concerning this.
11: <sup>11</sup> Wisdom is good with an inheritance: and by it there is profit to them that see the sun.
12: <sup>12</sup> For wisdom is a defence, and money is a defence: but the excellency of knowledge is, that wisdom giveth life to them that have it.
13: <sup>13</sup> Consider the work of God: for who can make that straight, which he hath made crooked?
14: <sup>14</sup> In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider: God also hath set the one over against the other, to the end that man should find nothing after him.
15: <sup>15</sup> All things have I seen in the days of my vanity: there is a just man that perisheth in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his wickedness.
16: <sup>16</sup> Be not righteous over much; neither make thyself over wise: why shouldest thou destroy thyself?
17: <sup>17</sup> Be not over much wicked, neither be thou foolish: why shouldest thou die before thy time?
18: <sup>18</sup> It is good that thou shouldest take hold of this; yea, also from this withdraw not thine hand: for he that feareth God shall come forth of them all.
19: <sup>19</sup> Wisdom strengtheneth the wise more than ten mighty men which are in the city.
20: <sup>20</sup> For there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not.
21: <sup>21</sup> Also take no heed unto all words that are spoken; lest thou hear thy servant curse thee:
22: <sup>22</sup> For oftentimes also thine own heart knoweth that thou thyself likewise hast cursed others.
23: <sup>23</sup> All this have I proved by wisdom: I said, I will be wise; but it was far from me.
24: <sup>24</sup> That which is far off, and exceeding deep, who can find it out?
25: <sup>25</sup> I applied mine heart to know, and to search, and to seek out wisdom, and the reason of things, and to know the wickedness of folly, even of foolishness and madness:
26: <sup>26</sup> And I find more bitter than death the woman, whose heart is snares and nets, and her hands as bands: whoso pleaseth God shall escape from her; but the sinner shall be taken by her.
27: <sup>27</sup> Behold, this have I found, saith the preacher, counting one by one, to find out the account:
28: <sup>28</sup> Which yet my soul seeketh, but I find not: one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among all those have I not found.
29: <sup>29</sup> Lo, this only have I found, that God hath made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions.
